titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Watson Cole Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled and edited by Steven Litwack and Peter Sargent

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 08:20

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Manuscripts, notes, working papers, correspondence, and other papers of George Watson Cole, bibliographer and librarian. Most of the papers pertain to various bibliographic problems and topics that Cole was interested in. There is also some material relating to his work as librarian for the Henry E. Huntington Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Watson Cole Papers (MS 143). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Cole estate and the American Antiquarian Society, 1942-1944.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Manuscripts. II. Subject File.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Watson Cole was born at Warren, Conn., September 6, 1850. His early education was received in the public schools of his native county and at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass. After teaching school for four years, during which time he read Law, he was admitted to the bar in 1876 and practiced law in his native county until 1885, when he abandoned law to engage in library work.

During 1885 and 1886 he compiled the printed Classified Catalogue of the Fitchburg (Mass.) Public Library . From Fitchburg he went to New York in the autumn of 1886 to become the Librarian of the Pratt Institute of Brooklyn; at the same time he attended the Library School at Columbia University, from which he was graduated in 1888. For the next three years he was connected with the Newberry Library in Chicago, which he left in January 1891 to become the Librarian of the Free Public Library of Jersey City, N.J., then being organized. In December 1895, because of ill-health, Mr. Cole resigned his position as Librarian and devoted the next three years to travel.

On his return to this country he became interested in bibliography; in December 1901, he began compilation of the extensive and valuable collection of American and English Literature and Miscellany in the Library of the late E. Dwight Church, of Brooklyn. The result of his labors was a catalogue comprising seven volumes, containing in all 3,789 pages, with 1,755 facsimiles of title pages, colophons and other interesting features of the collection.

In October 1915, Cole became Librarian of Henry E. Huntington's collection, then housed in New York. He continued to hold the position after the collection was transferred in 1920 to the present location of the Huntington Library in California.
In 1924 he became Librarian Emeritus. Thereafter he continued to publish articles and books on bibliographical and other topics. He died on October 10, 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts, notes, working papers, correspondence, and other papers of George Watson Cole, bibliographer and librarian. Most of the papers pertain to various bibliographic problems and topics that Cole was interested in. There is also some material relating to his work as librarian for the Henry E. Huntington Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains many minor manuscripts of articles, essays, speeches and fiction. The two main topics are bibliography and travel. Also included are essays on temperence and The Huntington Library.

Boxes 4 and 5 of this series contain material pertaining to G.W. Cole's edition of Ben Jonson's The Masque of the Gypsies . Included are photostatic copies of three 17th century texts that Cole employed in compiling his edition and correspondence pertaining to The Masque of the Gypsies .
Of particular interest is Cole's juxtaposition of the three 17th century texts and Cole's subsequent version. This includes a line by line comparision and Cole's notations of variences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains biographical information relating to G.W. Cole and general correspondence. Included in this are an article about Cole by Harold D. Carew ("Toiler in the Vineyard of Books") a list of the books in G.W. Cole's private library, and a list of G.W. Cole's printed productions.
Other material in this series includes a folder of general correspondence and a check list of Dickens' The Pickwick Papers .
